definitions.definition: to break something, or to be broken, violently and noisily into many pieces

examples.text: He smashed the radio to pieces.
The glass bowl smashed into a thousand pieces.
She flew into one of her rages and started smashing crockery.
His right hand was smashed and his shoulder dislocated.

definitions.definition: to move with a lot of force against something solid; to make something do this

examples.text: the sound of waves smashing against the rocks
The car smashed into a tree.
Mark smashed his fist down on the desk.
A bullet smashed into the wall behind them.
Ram-raiders smashed a stolen car through the shop window.

definitions.definition: to hit something very hard and break it, in order to get through it
definitions.sensetop: smash something + adv./prep.smash something + adj.+ adv./prep.

examples.text: They had to smash holes in the ice.
The elephant smashed its way through the trees.
We had to smash the door open.
They had smashed through a glass door to get in.
He smashed the ball into the goal.

definitions.definition: to break a record by a large amount

examples.text: She has smashed the world record.

definitions.definition: to destroy, defeat or put an end to something/somebody

examples.text: Police say they have smashed a major drugs ring.

definitions.definition: to hit a high ball downwards and very hard over the net
to do something very well or be very successful

examples.text: After all that training, I’m sure he’ll smash it in the competition tonight.

wordOrigin: early 18th cent. (as a noun): probably imitative, representing a blend of words such as smack, smite with bash, mash, etc.
